member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.NumericTextBase`2.ParseFormattedValue(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a data value from a string representation.
member.remarks:
If throws a or an , attempts to manually handle any fractional or exponential notation in the formatted input value before calling again.
takes the following steps when performing fallback handling:
If represents an integer data type and
returns , then the scientific exponential notation in the formatted input value is flattened into the equivalent text value. For example, 1.2e3 is converted to 120 and re-parsed, resulting in a final value of 120.
If represents an integer data type and the formatted input value contains a decimal point, then
is used to determine whether the final value should be rounded. For example, 1.8 is converted to 1, re-parsed, and rounded up, resulting in a final value of 2.
If throws an , then the value is coerced to or , using to determine the direction of overflow.
Otherwise, the parse is considered unsuccessful and the formatted value is restored to its original formatted input value.
member.returns: The data value equivalent of .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.NumericTextBase`2.ShouldCharacterCauseRoundingAwayFromZero(System.Char,System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified character causes a parsed value to round to the next integer value away from zero.
member.remarks: The default implementation tests whether the specified character is one of the base-10 rounding characters 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9.
member.param: The last integral character of the incoming text value.
The set of fractional characters of the incoming text value.
member.returns: if the character should cause the parsed value to round to the next integer value away from zero; otherwise, to truncate the parsed value to the current integer.

member.summary: Updates the value while being dragged by the user at run time, then returns to the original value at release.

remarks.para: You can use , , and to change the appearance of the slider, and use , , and to interact with the slider at run time.

The track behind the thumb fills with the brush as the thumb moves along. By changing the property to Transparent you can have a thumb that moves along a track without leaving any trail behind it.
The default data type for the slider control is . To change the data type, right-click the slider on the Visual Studio Designer, select Data Type, then select a different data type.

member.summary: Represents a Measurement Studio Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) control to display and manipulate numeric values in various bases.
member.typeparam: The type of data used by the control.
member.remarks:
Typically, you use the radix numeric text box as either an indicator or an input control for a single integer numeric value that may need to be displayed or edited in a non-standard numeric base. This can be accomplished by setting to , , , or , or by changing the radix base at run time via a drop list on the control.
You can use , , and all the font properties to change the appearance of the radix numeric text box, and use , , , and
to determine how a user can interact with the control at run time.
defines the range of valid values for the control. You can set the property to allow either continuous or discrete values.
The default data type for the radix numeric text box is . To change the data type, right-click the meter on the Visual Studio Designer, select Data Type, then select a different data type. Continuous data types such as and are not available.
